datafield.subfield: George Robert Swain photographs and papers,
20 linear ft. (in 34 boxes) and 1 oversize folder.
Official photographer for the University of Michigan.

Trained as an educator and a self-taught photographer, George Swain worked as a high school principal after graduating from the University of Michigan in 1900. From 1913 until his death in 1947, he was the official photographer for the University. This work included documentation of several photographic journeys made with Professor Francis W. Kelsey of the Latin Department, sponsored by the university's Near East Research Center.

While on expedition, Swain photographed excavation sites, rare manuscripts, and ancient ruins. His on-site university work included the production of lantern slides that were used in conjunction with class lectures. Additionally, he broadly documented university buildings and campus activities and made portraits of professors, Ann Arbor families and campus groups.

Swain also conducted a private photographic practice, and with his wife Edith directed a summer camp for girls near Alpena and at Lake Charlevoix, Michigan. Swain's personal work focused on landscapes, cityscapes, waterscapes, campus views, family portraits and images taken on family camping trips. The collection includes a group of images capturing western portions of the United States and Canada in the early twentieth century.

The Swain collection is comprised of three series: Miscellaneous Papers, Photographs: Prints, and Photographs: Negatives. The bulk of the collection consists of early twentieth century images of Ann Arbor and the University of Michigan, although there are several folders of photographs Swain made while traveling abroad with Professor Francis W. Kelsey as photographic technician for the University of Michigan's Near East Research Center.

These latter images form part of the Miscellaneous Papers Series and are frequently accompanied by lengthy captions and/or typewritten text. Also included in this series is a volume of letters Swain wrote to his family while traveling abroad in 1924; essays and reports related to a 1925 expedition; a diary of camping trips on the Au Sable River, 1904-1908; a diary jointly kept by George and Edith Swain, 1900;

a University of Michigan English composition student notebook; and a small folder of genealogical material. There are two sets of photographs -- Set One, which relates to a carefully prepared index Swain maintained and Set Two, which has no index. The Photographs: Prints series holds approximately two feet of mainly Ann Arbor and University of Michigan area realted images -- campus buildings, portraits, landscapes, cityscapes -- most of which are part of Set One.

Many of these prints are photographs presumably printed by Swain; others, however, are black and white copy prints prepared for reference purposes. The Photographs: Negatives series forms the bulk of the collection and includes over six hundred glass plate negatives of various sizes, as well as film negatives, also of varying sizes.
Finding aid available via World Wide Web at URL: http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/f/findaid/findaid-idx?c=bhlead&idno=umich-bhl-86169
University of Michigan Near East Research Expedition
